item.title: Law and Economics: Rational and Objective or Fundamentally Unjust?
item.description:
We are happy to announce our Philosophy Talk of the term presented by Professor Patricia Marino, Law and economics: rational and objective or fundamentally unjust?
WHEN: Wednesday November 5th at 5pm WHERE: Hagey Hall Room 345 DESCRIPTION: Law and economics is the application of economic theory to legal reasoning: in this increasingly influential approach, laws are understood not in terms of justice and rights, but rather as efficient solutions to the problems of organizing society. In normative law and economics, the aim of the legal system is to maximize social welfare. Normative law and economics thus echoes the ethical theory of utilitarianism, where the right action is the one that produces the best consequences. Like utilitarianism, law and economics reasoning faces challenges to do with ethical values such as justice, fairness, and equality: what if the best consequences sacrifice some people's interests for the good of others, increase inequality, or violate other ethical norms? In this talk, I showcase these problems through examples related to tax policy, environmental injustice, and health care resource allocation; I then explain how proponents of law and economics respond to these challenges. We can then discuss together whether law and economics is a rational, objective alternative to arbitrary decision-making or whether its recommendations can be fundamentally unjust.
Snacks and drinks will be provided. This talk is open to all members of the UW community, no experience or expertise in philosophy required. We hope to see you there for an interesting philosophy talk and discussion on philosophy of economics!

item.title: Dinner With the LSA
item.description:
Please join us this Friday at 6pm for a dinner and consultation with the Local Spiritual Assembly of Waterloo!
This event is open to all new and returning post-secondary students in the Waterloo region, whether you have attended a CABS event or notâ€¦ so bring your friends!!
Feel free to DM if you have any questions. See you there â¤ï¸
Image details: Friday, 7 November â€” 6:00 - 9:00 PM at SLC 2134. Everyone is welcome.

the work we do happens on the traditional territory of the neutral, Anishinaabeg and Haudenosaunee peoples. The land we work on is covered by the LINK: Betweenthe Lakes Treaty, No. 3 (1792) -> https://www.ontario.ca/page/map-ontario-treaties-and-reserves Between the Lakes Treaty, No. 3 (1792) , and this region is still home to First Nation, Inuit, and Metis peoples from across Turtle Island. We are grateful to have the opportunity to work, play and live on this land and ackno wledge that it is our collective responsibility to make our community and world a better place for all people. We acknowledge that educational institutions have not been a safe space for Indigenous students in the past and we continue to work to ensure that this is no longer the case. The work towards truth and reconciliation is ongoing, please do your part and take time to learn more: LINK: TRC 94 Calls to Action -> https://www2.gov.bc.ca/assets/gov/british-columbians-our-governments/indigenous-people/aboriginal-peoples-documents/calls_to_action_english2.pdf TRC 94 Calls to Action | LINK: MMIWG Calls to Justice Report -> https://www.mmiwg-ffada.ca/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Calls_for_Justice.pdf MMIWG Calls to Justice Report | LINK: Native-Land.ca -> https://native-land.ca/ Native-Land.ca | LINK: Student Supports & Clubs -> https://uwaterloo.ca/indigenous/student-supports-and-clubs/student-supports-and-clubs Student Supports & Clubs Toggle Navigation LINK: Feedback -> https://wusa.ca/about/contact/#feedback Feedback LINK: General Inquiries -> https://uwaterloo.atlassian.net/servicedesk/customer/portal/13/group/1573/create/3179?utm_medium=footer&utm_source=website General Inquiries LINK: Media Inquiries -> mailto:mmthomas@wusa.ca Media Inquiries LINK: Contact -> https://wusa.ca/about/contact/ Contact Â© 2025 Waterloo Undergraduate Student Association wrapper #boxed-wrapper LINK: Page load link -> # We use cookies on this site to enhance the user experience. item.title: Potluck Boardgame Night
item.description: Join us for a... Potluck Boardgame Night. Come get to know our club members! Optional: Bring some food to share.

item.title: Resume Building Workshop
item.description: Need a Resume? We've got you. On Friday, we'll be hosting a resume building workshop with Jean Denis Marcellin, Chief Pilot for Skyservice. No resume needed. We'll help you make your resume strong with insider tips and personalized feedback to set you up for success. This event is open to 2nd to 4th year students. Please RSVP with the link in our bio.

item.title: First-Year Movie Night
item.description: Oppenheimer is a pretty good movie, please come y'all. Join us for Oppenheimer, pizza, popcorn, drinks, and snacks @DC 1351!

item.title: Karaoke Night
item.description: It's time to de-stress from your midterms. What better way than belting out Elton John, ABBA, or Sinatra, on the stage at Revive. Band members: Invite your friends! General public: Meet the band members, learn about the band's! This event will be 19+. We'd love to meet you all before our big shows this term!

item.title: Badminton Ontario Circuit Tryouts
item.description:
BADMINTON ONTARIO CIRCUIT TRYOUTS â€¼ï¸ ðŸ—“ï¸ Weâ€™ll be hosting tryouts for our circuit team in two weeks, on Friday, November 7th, from 9:30 PM - 12:30 AM, during regular session. This is SEPARATE from varsityâ€™s team.
â€¼ï¸YOU MUST BE A UWBC MEMBER TO PARTICIPATE (unless otherwise stated by the team)
âœï¸ Applicants must fill out the registration form and will be required to pay a tryout fee of $5.
ðŸ‘Ÿ It is HIGHLY recommended to bring running shoes, along with your court shoes.
ðŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸â€âž¡ï¸ The first part of the tryout will be an outdoor run.
CIRCUIT INFORMATION ðŸ† Badminton Ontarioâ€™s new circuit aims to give university club players the opportunity to represent their school while playing high-level, competitive badminton.
ðŸ… This circuit will feature four tournaments, at the following locations: 1. Brock University (St. Catharines) 2. University of Waterloo (Waterloo) 3. University of Toronto (Scarborough) 4. Pan-Am Centre (Markham)
ðŸ¸ Each of these tournaments will feature 5 events: - MS - WS - MD - WD - XD
ðŸ‘¯ As such, weâ€™re aiming to take a maximum of 16 players. (8 men, 8 women).
ðŸ§‘â€ðŸ§’ We will also be taking subs based on term/individual availabilities and injuries.
âœ… Thanks, and I hope to see you all at tryouts!
ðŸ€ Best of luck!

item.title: Inter-University Karate Seminar
item.description: The University of Waterloo Karate and Jujitsu club will be hosting an Inter-University Karate Seminar on Saturday, November 8, 2025. We will be inviting and collaborating with many esteemed Karate instructors and various Universities to join us! The schedule is currently focused on developing Kihon in the morning and Kata/Bunkai in the afternoon, with a focus on Goju-Ryu and Shotokan style Karate!

November 8 @ 9:00 AM - 7:00 PM EST | $30.00 â€“ $40.00 Event content Ready for an Epic Day at Niagara Falls? ðŸŒŠ Get ready for a jaw-dropping adventure. Join us for a day at one of the worldâ€™s most iconic natural wonders â€” Niagara Falls! ðŸŒŸ Date: Saturday, November 8, 2025 Departure: 9:00 AM SHARP from Davis Centre Library (be there by 8:30 AM to avoid missing the bus!) Return: 5:00 PM from Table Rock Welcome Centre Prepare for an unforgettable day of stunning views, roaring falls, and tons of fun! Event Essentials WatCard and ticket required for check-in. This event is exclusive to Waterloo students. Weâ€™re excited to experience the power of Niagara Falls together. See you there â€” itâ€™s going to be epic ! ðŸŽŸï¸ Secure Your Tickets Below ðŸŽŸï¸ Your next adventure is just around the corner. Donâ€™t miss outâ€”grab your ticket now and make some unforgettable memories! ðŸ•” Ticket sales close Friday, November 7 at 12:00 PM. All tickets are final saleâ€”no refunds will be issued. The land we work on is covered by the LINK: Betweenthe Lakes Treaty, No. 3 (1792) -> https://www.ontario.ca/page/map-ontario-treaties-and-reserves Between the Lakes Treaty, No. 3 (1792) , and this region is still home to First Nation, Inuit, and Metis peoples from across Turtle Island. We are grateful to have the opportunity to work, play and live on this land and ackno wledge that it is our collective responsibility to make our community and world a better place for all people. We acknowledge that educational institutions have not been a safe space for Indigenous students in the past and we continue to work to ensure that this is no longer the case. Thai Food Class November 8 @ 11:00 AM - 8:30 PM EST | $20.00 Event content PLEASE NOTE: All attendees must fill out LINK: this waiver -> https://wusa.ca/waiver/uw-cooking-club-thai-food-cooking-class/ and may not be permitted into the event without having done so. Join the UW Cooking Club for a delicious cooking class on Saturday, November 8th! Weâ€™ll be making Pad thai, Mango salad and Thai tea! As always, we welcome all skill levels to our lessons, hope to see you there ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ³ðŸ¥ If you have any questions or dietary restrictions, shoot us a DM @uwcookingclub ðŸ™‚ Our classes are located at 19-105 Lexington Rd, Waterloo ON N2J 4R7 Reminders: Tie up long hair and wear closed-toed shoes. item.title: Tabletop Tavern
item.description:
Tabletop Tavern is here for its 5th running and we are back and better than ever! Sponsored by J&J Cards and Collectables & Ravenwood Tabletop, expect this now six-way collab event in SLC 1123 (The Bomber) Sat, Nov. 8th from 12-11pm between UW Board Games Club, WATSFiC, Deceptions Board Games, PokÃ©mon Club, Yu-Gi-Oh Club, and the Magic the Gathering Club to be a day you donâ€™t want to miss!
Come for a day of scheduled events, live performances, a raffle for prizes (sponsored by J&Jâ€™s and Ravenwood), a drinks bar (non-alcoholic), snacks, for-loan games (given you provide your WATCard or Valid ID), items for sale, and so much more!
For each scheduled event you take part in you will get a raffle ticket for a chance to win amazing sponsored prizes at the end of the night! The winners of WATSFiCâ€™s D&D tournament get an additional ticket towards the raffle. To sign-up for WATSFiCâ€™s tournament and guarantee a seat, please see their discord server posts. Walk-in is also available. Any volunteer DMs will also get a free drink from our drinks bar for your efforts!
Again, a big thanks to @jjcardsandcollectibles and @ravenwoodtabletop.ca for agreeing to sponsor the event and offer our raffle prizes, @acornpeanuts for the front poster design, @daidd_an for the rest of the poster designs, and to all the organizing clubs (@uwboardgames @uwdeception @uwyugioh @uwatsfic @uw_pokemon_club and Magic the Gathering) for working so hard to put this all together. We couldnâ€™t have done it without you!
So with that being said, we hope to see you at Tabletop Tavern this term as we get back into the full swing of things! Check each clubâ€™s Discord server announcements for more details. If you want to keep up with each club, donâ€™t hesitate to check out what they have coming up after and/or leading up to Tabletop Tavern!

The land we work on is covered by the LINK: Betweenthe Lakes Treaty, No. 3 (1792) -> https://www.ontario.ca/page/map-ontario-treaties-and-reserves Between the Lakes Treaty, No. 3 (1792) , and this region is still home to First Nation, Inuit, and Metis peoples from across Turtle Island. We are grateful to have the opportunity to work, play and live on this land and ackno wledge that it is our collective responsibility to make our community and world a better place for all people. We acknowledge that educational institutions have not been a safe space for Indigenous students in the past and we continue to work to ensure that this is no longer the case. The work towards truth and reconciliation is ongoing, please do your part and take time to learn more: LINK: TRC 94 Calls to Action -> https://www2.gov.bc.ca/assets/gov/british-columbians-our-governments/indigenous-people/aboriginal-peoples-documents/calls_to_action_english2.pdf TRC 94 Calls to Action | LINK: MMIWG Calls to Justice Report -> https://www.mmiwg-ffada.ca/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Calls_for_Justice.pdf MMIWG Calls to Justice Report | LINK: Native-Land.ca -> https://native-land.ca/ Native-Land.ca | LINK: Student Supports & Clubs -> https://uwaterloo.ca/indigenous/student-supports-and-clubs/student-supports-and-clubs Student Supports & Clubs Toggle Navigation LINK: Feedback -> https://wusa.ca/about/contact/#feedback Feedback LINK: General Inquiries -> https://uwaterloo.atlassian.net/servicedesk/customer/portal/13/group/1573/create/3179?utm_medium=footer&utm_source=website General Inquiries LINK: Media Inquiries -> mailto:mmthomas@wusa.ca Media Inquiries LINK: Contact -> https://wusa.ca/about/contact/ Contact Â© 2025 Waterloo Undergraduate Student Association wrapper #boxed-wrapper LINK: Page load link -> # We use cookies on this site to enhance the user experience. item.title: Battle of the Jazz Bands
item.description: Its the event of the season! Come watch jazz bands from the University of Toronto, McMaster University and the University of Waterloo battle it out on the Hagey Hall Theater stage from 2:00-4:30 pm on November 9th. This will be our largest event yet and definitely the first of its kind. Bring everyone you know to attend this FREE concert.

item.title: Girlsâ€™ Climb
item.description: Our Girlsâ€™ Climb is back!! This time, weâ€™ll be hosting a members only meetup at the PAC wall complete with bouldering, top ropes, and snacks of course! Climbing can be intimidating, but it doesnâ€™t have to be, which is why we want to create a chill space where climbers can connect and support each other. Whether youâ€™re a seasoned climber or just getting into it, come hang out and send with us! âœ¨

item.title: Claude Builder Club Cafe
item.description:
Need a cozy space to work, recharge, or make friends? Join us for the first of its kind Claude Builder Cafe in Waterloo: a relaxed afternoon of co-working, creative challenges, and free drinks.
Whether youâ€™re debugging, designing, or just catching up on coursework, this is your place to plug in and unwind.
What to expect: â€¢ Free cafÃ© drinks and snacks â€¢ Co-working sessions with a chill study vibe â€¢ Fun mini break challenges with merch prizes â€¢ A chance to connect with the Claude Builder Club community
ðŸ“ 1st floor IDEAS Clinic (E7-1427) ðŸ—“ï¸ Sunday Nov 9 â° 2:00 - 5:30 PM (drop in anytime) â˜•ï¸ Free entry - just sign up with the link in our bio
See you there ðŸ§¡

item.title: Fall 2025 League
item.description: Sign up now for our Fall 2025 League! 6 weeks of curling, all skill levels welcome! Membership is $90. Use the link in our bio to fill out the Google Form and Sign Up on Athletics (2 forms to fill out).

item.title: Humans vs Zombies Weeklong
item.description: Weeklong signups are now open! The termly HvZ weeklong returns November 10th to 14th. This time, you'll be joining the set of Game Changer as cast or crew as they shoot a zombie-based episode. Signups are, as always, on our website at https://uwhvz.uwaterloo.ca/, or in person at our SLC booth on Monday and Friday Never played a weeklong? Get the rundown on our website. Even if you've played before, take a moment to brush up on the rules at https://tinyurl.com/TasJpbCsu9.

item.title: Midterm Recovery Kit Sale
item.description: Take a study break and treat yourself to our Midterm Recovery Kits! Stop by the SLC Marketplace on November 10th to grab yours!

item.title: Boba Tea & Waffles
item.description: Come to our Mental Health Week events next Monday through Friday! Boba Tea & Waffles from 11AM to 12:30PM @ ESS Lounge.

The land we work on is covered by the LINK: Betweenthe Lakes Treaty, No. 3 (1792) -> https://www.ontario.ca/page/map-ontario-treaties-and-reserves Between the Lakes Treaty, No. 3 (1792) , and this region is still home to First Nation, Inuit, and Metis peoples from across Turtle Island. We are grateful to have the opportunity to work, play and live on this land and ackno wledge that it is our collective responsibility to make our community and world a better place for all people. We acknowledge that educational institutions have not been a safe space for Indigenous students in the past and we continue to work to ensure that this is no longer the case. The work towards truth and reconciliation is ongoing, please do your part and take time to learn more: LINK: TRC 94 Calls to Action -> https://www2.gov.bc.ca/assets/gov/british-columbians-our-governments/indigenous-people/aboriginal-peoples-documents/calls_to_action_english2.pdf TRC 94 Calls to Action | LINK: MMIWG Calls to Justice Report -> https://www.mmiwg-ffada.ca/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Calls_for_Justice.pdf MMIWG Calls to Justice Report | LINK: Native-Land.ca -> https://native-land.ca/ Native-Land.ca | LINK: Student Supports & Clubs -> https://uwaterloo.ca/indigenous/student-supports-and-clubs/student-supports-and-clubs Student Supports & Clubs Toggle Navigation LINK: Feedback -> https://wusa.ca/about/contact/#feedback Feedback LINK: General Inquiries -> https://uwaterloo.atlassian.net/servicedesk/customer/portal/13/group/1573/create/3179?utm_medium=footer&utm_source=website General Inquiries LINK: Media Inquiries -> mailto:mmthomas@wusa.ca Media Inquiries LINK: Contact -> https://wusa.ca/about/contact/ Contact Â© 2025 Waterloo Undergraduate Student Association wrapper #boxed-wrapper LINK: Page load link -> # We use cookies on this site to enhance the user experience. item.title: Real Talk & Resumes
item.description:
Join us on Monday November 10th from 4-6pm in ML 349 for a night of learning and fun!
Hear from upper-year students as they share their experiences navigating co-op and the challenges that come with it! Reflect on your career and purpose, in and outside of co-op.
There will also be a time to get your resume reviewed, so scan the QR code or click on the link in our bio to sign up (walk-ins are also welcome)!
Poster title: REAL TALK & RESUMES (presented by P2C). The poster also lists the room as Modern Languages 349 and includes a QR code to sign up for resume reviews.

item.title: Grad School 101
item.description: You heard it here first folks! The English Society is partnering up with the Student Association for Graduates in English (SAGE) to answer all of your burning questions about Grad School. From the application process to the realities of being a grad student in UW English, weâ€™ll get to hear firsthand from MA and PhD students. Submit your questions ahead of time using the Form in our LinkTree!

We acknowledge that educational institutions have not been a safe space for Indigenous students in the past and we continue to work to ensure that this is no longer the case. Select 'Accept all' to agree and continue. You consent to our cookies if you continue to use this website. LINK: Accept all -> # LINK: Go to Top -> # Go to Top Notifications
STRICT CONTENT POLICY: - ONLY extract an event if the post is clearly announcing or describing a real-world event with BOTH: * a specific date (e.g., "October 31", "Friday", "tomorrow") * AND a specific start time (e.g., "at 2pm", "from 10am-4pm", "noon", "evening"). - DO NOT extract an event if there is no explicit mention of a start time. Do NOT default to midnight or any other time if none is given. - DO NOT extract an event if: * The post is a meme, personal photo dump, or generic post with no time/place. * The post is inappropriate (nudity, explicit sexual content, or graphic violence). * There is no explicit mention of BOTH a date (e.g., "October 31", "Friday", "tomorrow") AND a time (e.g., "at 2pm", "from 10am-4pm", "noon", "evening") in the caption or image. * The post only introduces people or some topic, UNLESS there is a clear call to attend or participate in an actual event (such as a meeting, workshop, performance, or competition).
If you determine that there is NO event in the post, return the JSON value: null (not an object, not an array, just the literal null). Otherwise, return an array of JSON objects with ALL of the following fields: { "title": string, "dtstart": string, // local start in "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS+HH" "dtend": string, // local end in "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS+HH" or empty string "dtstart_utc": string, // UTC start "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SSZ" or empty string "dtend_utc": string, // UTC end "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SSZ" or empty string "duration": string, // "HH:MM:SS" or empty string "all_day": boolean, "location": string, "latitude": number or null, "longitude": number or null, "tz": string, "price": number or null, "food": string, "registration": boolean, "rrule": string, "rdate": string, // comma-separated datetime strings in format "YYYYMMDDTHHMMSS,YYYYMMDDTHHMMSS,..." (e.g., "20251113T170000,20251204T170000,20251218T170000") "school": string, "source_image_url": string, "description": string, "categories": list // one or more of the following, as a JSON array of strings: - Academic - Career & Networking - Social & Games - Athletics - Creative Arts - Cultural - Religious - Advocacy & Causes - Sales & Fundraising }
CONSOLIDATION RULES (VERY IMPORTANT): - If multiple dates/times describe the SAME event (same title/location/content), CONSOLIDATE into ONE object: * Put the primary occurrence in dtstart/dtend. * For additional dates: use EITHER rdate (for specific dates without a pattern) OR rrule (for a clear recurring pattern like "every Monday"). * IMPORTANT: Use EITHER rrule OR rdate, NEVER both. If using rdate, set rrule to "". If using rrule, set rdate to "". * Never create separate objects for the same event just because of multiple dates. - Only create multiple objects when the caption clearly describes DISTINCT events (different titles, venues, or clearly different activities).
RDATE vs RRULE RULES (CRITICAL):
MUTUAL EXCLUSIVITY (MANDATORY): - RRULE and RDATE are MUTUALLY EXCLUSIVE - you must use EITHER one OR the other, NEVER both. - If an event has multiple specific dates with NO recurring pattern, use RDATE only (rrule must be ""). - If an event has a recurring pattern (e.g., "every Monday", "weekly on Wednesdays", "daily"), use RRULE only (rdate must be ""). - If an event has no recurrence or additional dates, both rrule and rdate should be empty strings "".
- Use RDATE when multiple specific dates are listed but NO recurring pattern is explicitly stated: * Example: "Join us Oct 15, Oct 22, Nov 3, and Nov 10" -> Use RDATE with the additional dates, rrule must be "" * RDATE should be a comma-separated string of datetime values in format YYYYMMDDTHHMMSS * Example: "20251022T140000,20251103T140000,20251110T140000" * Put the first occurrence in dtstart/dtend, remaining dates/times in rdate * When using RDATE, always set rrule to ""
- Use RRULE when a recurring pattern IS explicitly stated (e.g., "every Monday", "weekly on Wednesdays", "daily"): * DO NOT USE RRULE IF THE EVENT HAS NO RECURRING PATTERN * RRULE MUST include the UNTIL parameter to specify when the recurrence ends * Format: FREQ=WEEKLY;BYDAY=MO;UNTIL=20251231T235959Z * If no end date is mentioned, use 20251231T235959Z as the UNTIL value * Common RRULE examples: - Every Wednesday until December: FREQ=WEEKLY;BYDAY=WE;UNTIL=20251130T235959Z - Daily for a week: FREQ=DAILY;UNTIL=20251110T235959Z - Every Tuesday and Thursday: FREQ=WEEKLY;BYDAY=TU,TH;UNTIL=20251215T235959Z * When using RRULE, always set rdate to ""
MULTIPLE TIME SLOTS FOR SAME RECURRING EVENT: When the same event has multiple time slots on the same day(s) of the week, create SEPARATE event objects for each time slot. Example: "Weekly sessions every Wednesday: 5-6 PM and 8-10 PM through December" Should create TWO event objects: [ { "...": "...", "dtstart": "2025-11-05 17:00:00-05", "dtend": "2025-11-05 18:00:00-05", "dtstart_utc": "2025-11-05 22:00:00Z", "dtend_utc": "2025-11-05 23:00:00Z", "duration": "01:00:00", "all_day": false, "rrule": "FREQ=WEEKLY;BYDAY=WE;UNTIL=20251231T235959Z", "rdate": "", }, { "...": "...", "dtstart": "2025-11-05 20:00:00-05", "dtend": "2025-11-05 22:00:00-05", "dtstart_utc": "2025-11-06 01:00:00Z", "dtend_utc": "2025-11-06 03:00:00Z", "duration": "02:00:00", "rrule": "FREQ=WEEKLY;BYDAY=WE;UNTIL=20251231T235959Z", "rdate": "", } ] This represents two separate recurring time slots (5-6 PM and 8-10 PM) on every Wednesday from November through December.
ADDITIONAL RULES: - Prioritize caption text; use image text if missing details. - Title-case event titles. - If year not found, assume 2025. If end time < start time (e.g., 7pm-12am), set end to next day. - When no explicit date is found but there are relative terms like "tonight", "tomorrow", use the current date context and the date the post was made to determine the date. - Convert local times to UTC using tz for dtstart_utc/dtend_utc when available. - For all_day: ONLY set to true if the post **explicitly states** it is an all-day event (e.g., "all day", "full day"). - For location: Use the exact location as stated in the caption or image. If the location is a building or room on campus, use only that (e.g., "SLC 3223", "DC Library"). Include city/province if the event is off-campus and the address is provided. - For latitude/longitude: attempt to geocode the location if it's a specific address or well-known place (e.g., "DC Library"). Otherwise, attempt geocoding using the school context. Use null if location is too vague or cannot be geocoded. - For tz mappings, default to "America/Toronto" for University of Waterloo. - For price: this represents REGISTRATION COST ONLY. When multiple prices are mentioned, prefer the price that applies to NON-MEMBERS (or general admission). Rules: * If both "non-member" / "general admission" and "member" prices appear, use the non-member/general admission numeric price. * If only member prices are given and non-member price is absent, use the listed member price. * If multiple ticket tiers are listed (e.g., "early bird" and "regular"), use the lowest applicable price (e.g., early bird price). * Parse dollar amounts and return a numeric value (e.g., "$15" -> 15.0). Use null for free events or when no price is mentioned. - For food: Only set this field if the post says food or drinks will be served, provided, or available for attendees. If specific food or beverage items are mentioned (e.g., "pizza", "bubble tea", "snacks"), list them separated by commas and capitalize ONLY the first item. If the post explicitly says food is provided but does not specify what kind (e.g., "free food", "food provided", "there will be food"), output "Yes!" (exactly). If there is no mention of food or drinks, output an empty string "". - For registration: only set to true if there is a clear instruction to register, RSVP, or sign up, otherwise set to false. - For rrule and rdate: they are MUTUALLY EXCLUSIVE. Use EITHER rrule (for recurring patterns) OR rdate (for specific dates without a pattern), NEVER both. If using rrule, set rdate to "". If using rdate, set rrule to "". - For description: start with the caption text word-for-word, then append any additional insights about the event extracted from the image that are not already mentioned in the caption. - If information is not available, use empty string for strings, null for price/coordinates, and false for booleans. - Return ONLY the JSON array text, no extra commentary.

item.title: Navigating Whatâ€™s Next With Your Arts Degree
item.description: If the future feels uncertain, youâ€™re not alone! In this workshop, you will: â€¢Identify your key skills, interests, and values, and learn how they connect to potential career paths. â€¢Discover ways to pivot and reframe your experiences to open up new opportunities. â€¢Explore practical strategies to test your ideas, such as informational interviews, short term projects, or volunteering. â€¢Leave with a clearer sense of direction and concrete next steps to begin your journey. item.title: STANK: Serve's Thanksgiving Annual N(v)olleyball Kompetition
item.description: ðŸ¥§ Prepare for a Feast of Fierce Volleyball! ðŸ¦ƒ As the leaves turn and the holiday spirit fills the air, itâ€™s time for STANK: Serveâ€™s Thanksgiving Annual N(v)olleyball Kompetition! Gather your team, bring your best plays, and get ready to serve up gratitude with spikes, digs, and fierce rallies. Letâ€™s celebrate the season with some friendly competition and a full plate of fun! Event Details: ðŸ Date: Saturday, November 15th-16th (Overnight) â° Time: 8pm to 8am ðŸ“ Location: PAC Main Gym + Small Gym ðŸ‚ Team Sign-Up Form your crew of 6 to 9 players (only UWaterloo students with a valid athletics membership or alumni with a day pass) and choose your division: semi-competitive or competitive. Co-ed rules apply: all teams must have at least 2 female-identifying players on the court at all times. (Note: A female libero is required to serve for a middle.) âš ï¸ NEW Semi-Comp Sign-Up Rules (Read Carefully!) To keep play balanced and fair this season: - Any male-identifying player rated Level 5 or of Level 5 ability must set or lib on a semi-comp team. - If you attended UW prior to the 5-level system (graduated before Fall 2023), the same rule applies if you were rated Level 4. - Spring levels are not included in this consideration. - If thereâ€™s any confusion, please reach out to an exec for clarification. - If your team has a Level 5 male player signed up for semi-comp, contact an exec to verify the validity of your team. - Players who are not evaluated this term may be removed from your team on the day of or asked to set/lib if necessary. ðŸ’° Pricing Regular (still fresh out of the coop): Register by Nov 3rd for $200 Both the form and payment must be completed by Nov 3rd @ 11:59pm. ðŸ“ How to Register Make your payment: https://warrior.uwaterloo.ca/Program/GetProgramDetails?courseId=e7072bd1-0754-4e99-9fbe-04a18228cfe1 Fill out the form: https://forms.office.com/r/twpLDkzmhD @everyone ðŸ Letâ€™s spice up the season, rally together, and make this Thanksgiving one to remember!

item.title: AMATH Prof Talk
item.description:
Come join us for an AMATH Prof Talk on neural networks and dynamical systems!
Abstract: In machine learning, neural networks are often used in a feed-forward manner. Or, when a population of neurons is recurrently connected, the updates happen in synchronized jumps. But the neurons in your brain are operating in continuous time. I will show you some ways to bridge the gap to biology, and treat networks of interconnected neurons as a dynamical system. Then, we'll co-opt those networks to do our bidding, and get them to solve dynamical systems.
Pizza and refreshments will be provided to PMC members.

item.title: From Outages to Ownership
item.description:
From Outages to Ownership: Disaster Recovery, DNS, and Career Journeys in Okta Engineering
Ready to see how a top tech company handles the really big challenges? Join us and our Okta engineers for an evening focused on the critical work that keeps our services running; even when major outages happen. Our Staff Software Engineer will kick off the event with a fascinating technical talk, diving into DNS, redundancy, and disaster recovery based on her real-world experience at Okta. Itâ€™s a timely look at how engineering teams build for reliability at scale.
After the deep-dive, youâ€™ll hear from a panel of Engineers from various teams as they share their own career paths, offer a peek into their day-to-day work, and give you practical advice for launching your career. Stick around for our informal networking mixer to connect one-on-one with the team and ask any final questions!
ðŸ”— Link in bio to register

item.title: Womenâ€™s Centre X Glow Centre Chest Casting Workshop
item.description: Join the Womenâ€™s Centre and Glow on Friday, November 21 in the Womenâ€™s Centre (SLC 3104) for an event celebrating your body in a safe environment! Create a plaster cast of your chest as a way to honour and connect with your body. No matter the size and shape of your bust, every woman-identifying person and non-binary-identifying person is welcome at the event! There will also be a discussion on the sexualization and feminization of chests, and how these narratives can perpetuate transphobia and body image issues. Together, weâ€™ll explore new ways of seeing our bodies to help foster more positive and affirming self-perception. Registration will be open from November 3 through November 21 at 3 p.m., or until all available spots are filled. Please register early to secure your place using the link below!

item.title: University of Waterloo Accounting Conference 2025
item.description: The UWAC Team is thrilled to announce that registration for UWAC 2025 is now open! Register for a chance to compete for cash prizes, build valuable skills through sponsor-led workshops, and connect with students and industry professionals at Canadaâ€™s leading undergraduate accounting conference! The conference will take place on Saturday, November 22nd, hosted at Hagey Hall on the University of Waterloo campus. Teams will consist of four members, and you can either register with a group of friends or let us assign you a team. The registration deadline is FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 7TH at 11:59 PM, but sign up before November 2nd to take advantage of our early bird pricing and save $10! Early bird pricing (until November 2nd): $20 Regular pricing: $30 Sign up by paying for the ticket on the WUSA website AND submitting your application using our Google Form. You must complete BOTH forms to officially register! Spots are limited and will be assigned on a first-come, first-served basis, so make sure every team member signs up! For any questions or concerns, reach out to us at info@uwac.ca or through our social media. We canâ€™t wait to see you at the conference on November 22nd!

item.title: Voices Empower Walk
item.description: Join us for the Voices Empower Walk on November 22. Meet at the UWaterloo ION Station at 12:20 PM or at Uptown Square before 1 PM. The event runs from 1â€“4 PM. Everyone is welcome. Every six days in Canada, a woman is killed by her intimate partner. In 2024 alone, 187 femicides were recorded nationwide 62 in Ontario between November 2023 and November 2024. This rise in violence demands action. We cannot stay silent. When we walk together, we honor those lost, stand with survivors, and raise funds to help women, gender-diverse people, and children move beyond violence. Together, we walk for change. ðŸ’œ
